Yes, the use of kites for military purposes was not limited to the Chinese during the Song dynasty, and other cultures have also utilized kites in various ways for warfare. 

For example, during World War I and World War II, kites were used for aerial reconnaissance and to help artillery adjust their aim. The British and American armies used large kites to lift observation platforms, cameras, and sensors to an altitude of up to 10,000 feet.

In Japan, kites were traditionally used as a signal device during battles, and this strategy was used in the Boshin War in 1868-1869. During the Korean War, American soldiers used kites fitted with high-intensity lights to fly over enemy positions at night, providing illumination for troops on the ground.

In conclusion, while the Chinese were pioneers in using kites for military purposes, other cultures have adopted these tactics for warfare in their own ways.
